addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

15
[92]
M
r
Bodeley to my L.
By
Ch
r
ofer Kennell
the Th
rer
s Deputye./

page.lettertext:
fol.184r
[M
r
Bu]
zenval
May it please yo
r
good L. M
r
Buzenval
complaineth, that her
Ma
tie
hath signified to
Mons
r
de Nocle
, that wheras he had notice
from me of
e pleasure of her Hig
nes
for soliciting
the
states
to send some further succo
rs
for
e
service of
France,
he should oppose himself
against it, wherein he saieth he was mista-
ken: for
at
e motion was not made in
any suche nature, as if her Ma
tie
had willed
that I should recommend it, but as a mater
altogether proceeding from my self. But
yet howsoever,
at he was willing to advance
it, and had spoken about it to
e states: as
he shewed me a note of his last Proposition
in their publicke assemblie: delcaring fur-
ther to me,
at
e
Kinge
himself by his l
re
s,
had requested both
e states, and Count Mau-
rice in
at matter: w
ch
he perceaved notwith-
standing was so disliked of the states, as he re-
pented him greatly of proposing it unto them.
And therefor findes himself grieved, that he
should be so taxed to Mons
r
de Nocle, and [not]
that letter of her Ma
tie
w
ch
was written to Count
Maurice. I had no neede in o
r
conference, to tell him all
at I had written in
my letters of his dealing: but to
e pointes w
ch
he delivered, I made him this answear.
That true it was at first, I did move
e ma-
ter to him by way of discourse, and to knowe
his advise, w
ch
was at suche time, as I knewe,
not howe her Hig
nes
was affected unto it. But
I shewed him shortly after,
at I had heard out
of
England,
and
at her Ma
tie
was resolved
to propose
it
to
e states. And as for him he knewe
fol.184v
very well, that though he seemed to me to [em]
brace it at first, yet presently after in an [other]
communication he framed all his reasons [to per-]
suade me and others, not to urge
e mater [fur-]
ther. I putte him in minde of all his arg[uments]
That this contrey already had done much [for]
the Kinge, That it would
not
doe well, to dra[we too]
muche milke from a good milche cowe, T[hat]
when any more troupes should goe from hens [to]
France,
Parma
would be able, to send for [his]
forces from out of his Provinces, That by [ex-]
ploiting somwhat heere,
e forces of
e Enemie
would be greatly diverted from assisting [the]
Ligue, and
e Kinge
e lesse molested: w
t
o[ther]
like allegations. Wherupon, and because [.]
was a suite
at required most of all
e inst[.]
of
e Kinge, it would be expected at my han[des]
that I should signifie expressely, w
at
was don[e]
in his behalf, by his Agent heere in place. A[nd]
therfor, as I told him, I lette her Ma
tie
u[nder]
stand, that we differed in judgement: [.]
[man] inclining, not to meddle in
e motion [.]
And where he shewed me a point in his Lat[er pro-]
position, w
ch
tended to request
e renforc[ement of]
those succo
rs
, w
ch
are in service nowe in F[rance]
to
e nomber of 4000. I was plaine aga[in with]
him,
at it was but a worde cast out by
e [.]
among many other maters, and not pours[.]
suche remonstrance, as
e humor of this [.]
w
ch
he knewe well enough, and
at sub[.]
require. And for my self I did never [.]
but onely at this present, by his owne re[port]
or had altered any writte of his former [.]
he had spoken to
e states: or
at
e King [had]
addressed any letter unto them. Where [.]
fol.185r
if his meaning were in earnest, to bring the
mater to effect, it behooved him in reason, and
in good correspondence, for
e easier obtening of
his masters petition, to acquaint me w
t
his dea-
ling: both because
e first ouverture was made
by me unto him, and because I had told him,
at
her Ma
tie
was inclined, to seconde
at demaunde:
and also for
e credit of his maner of proceeding,
that I mght knowe
e occasion of
e alteration
of his minde, having seemed still before, to disal-
lowe
at
e states shoud be pressed in
e mater.
And where he alleged unto me, their dislike of his
proposall: I had reason to thinke it strange, when
of all
at I had sounded, w
ch
were divers of the
chiefest, I had not founde any one,
at was opposit
unto me: but onely douttfull of
e way to winne
e people to consent. Moreover, as I told
him very roundly, he faulted not onely in not ma-
king me privy to his forsaid dealing w
t
e states,
whereby we might have joined in preferring the
suite, but in secret communication w
t
Count Mau-
rice
and others, he reveled w
at
soever I had uttered
unto him, of my intention at first, and her Ma
ties
liking after, and of every other point, that was
in confered between us: and had bin in hand
w
t
S
r
Francis Vere
, to persuade me to surcease, from
dealing further in
e mater. He replied
againe unto me,
at although for himself in his
privat conceat, he was wholy against
it
, yet com-
maunded by
e Kinge, he did his endevo
r
in per-
suading
e states, whome he founde very back-
ward in
e Chapter, ho
w
soever I had founde their
privat disposition. And he thought it no preju-
dice to make it knowen to men before,
at suche a
motion was towardes, because in
e ende it was to
be divulged, and every man, he thought, would
favor
e better course. I will trouble
fol.185v
yo
r
L. w
t
no more: but this is
e effect of [.]
o
r
debate, in regard of his complaint of her [Majesties]
speeches: wherein we passed all o
r
talke w[ithout]
shewe of any passion. Howbeit by this mean[.]
knowe not w
at
to thinke will become of
e m[.]
For when a minister of
e Kinge, shall not [.]
not be willing to promote
e mater for him, [.]
shall labor underhand, to dissuade
e contrey [.]
from it, I see but litle cause to expect a goo[d]
event. For although for his credit, being [.]
ged by
e King, he hath solicited
e states a lo[.]
pro forma, yet to doe some pleasure to Count [Mau-]
rice, for so I finde it apparantly, he hath marr[ed]
all of purpose w
t
his couvert proceeding. B[ut]
yet to signifie to yo
r
L. privat conjecture
I thinke
e states in
e end, will seeme to gra[.]
her Ma
tie
in her present demaunde, by enlarging
their offers to
e warres of
Britaine.
I have [de-]
livered unto them her Ma
ties
l
re
of
e 17 of Ap[ril]
Presenting of y
r
H. l
re
s
to
e stat
& Comte
Maurice.
but according to their custome, they required
some time to make me an answear. The othe[r]
to Count Maurice was presented unto him by [Sir]
Francis Vere, who thought by suche meanes as [he]
had devised, to drawe him to say somw
at
of [.]
postscript of her Ma
tie
but he spake very w[.]
other then in generall, That he was highly [.]
unto her Hig
nes
and would give her satisf[action]
e best
e could. Yo
r
L. [letter]
of
e 10 of
e last, I receaved
e 30. T[he con-]
veiance therof, by those
at tooke
e charge [consi-]
dering howe
e winde hath served at will, [.]
neglected overmuche. About [the]
Placart/
mater of
e Placcart,
at was publsihed in [Bra-]
bant
, wherto yor L. desireth to receave a p[.]
answear, I have made as good enquirie, [as]
time will permitte, and will use some furth[er .]
nes to knowe as muche as may be. But [I can]
not yet perceave,that for
e point of tra[.]
fol.186r
between
e Enemie and those contreis, there is
any newe devise in any Placcart of
e Enemie.
For a kind of free trafficke hath bin alwaies per-
mitted by Placcarts on bothe sides, upon
e pai-
ment of suche customes, as are rated in their
Placcartes, but w
t
cautions and reserves in
certaine sortes of commodities. As by
e Placcarts
of these contreis, it is wholy prohibited to bring
in any clothes, silkes, or saies
at are made in
e Enemies contrey, or to transport to
e Enemie,
any kinde w
at
soever of warlicke provision: and
e like restraint is also made, of
e Enemies part.
All
e revenue raised heere, upon suche kinde of
customes,
e states doe convert, to maintene their
shippes of warre. Happely some Placcart
hath bin newly printed in Brabant, w
t
a change
of some pointes, as
e like is often heere, but
at
they hold an other course, then they have done heere
tofore, I can not learne it yet of any. If yo
r
L. hath
e Placcart, and shall be pleased to send
it hither, I shall be able fourthw
t
to give yo
w
cer-
taine informati
o
, in w
at
maner it is practised.
And for
at w
ch
is last in
e letter of
yo
r
L. I doe humbly beseeche yo
w
,
at it may not
[his] [revocac
o
n]
be
e last in yo
r
honorable remembrance, That
her Hig
nes
may be moved, to graunt me licence
to returne. My privat poore estate is very
casually left by my
fathers
decease, and I am dam-
mified daily by reason of mine absence: for w
ch
I
account my self surcharged both heere and at
home. The affaires of this state
doe stand at a stay, every man attending
e
successe of thinges in France. Howbeit it is in
part resolved,
at fourten daies hens, they will
into
e feelde, for
e siege of
steenwicke:
w
ch
if it
can be gotten, will put
e Province of
Frise
in
a great assurance. It is both strongely fortified,
and manned and victualed, and they expect
fol.186v
o
r
comming thither,
at it can not choose in [.]
but cost us very deere. The En[emie]
hath bin long, about a practise to surprise [the]
towne of
Enchusen.
His meanes to woorke [.]
Practise for surprising
of Enchusen./
by an inhabitant of
e towne, and a seam[.]
profession: who hath had often conference [with]
e
Spanishe king
himself, and hath receave[d at]
his handes, and of Parma in like sort, very [great]
summes of mony, partly in reward, and par[tly]
upon pretense,
at it was to be imploied in [cor-]
rupting
e Captaines, and certaine Burgm[asters]
But this mater hath bin disclosed to some of [.]
state by
e partie himself,
and
who
hath receaved [.]
suche direction,
at he hath tolled on
e Enemie, [.]
doe his enterprise in
e haven: w
ch
is to be exp[ec-]
ted some time
e next weeke, and w
t
some [thou]
sand men, if their present purpose hold, w
ch
[.]
be sent in an evening, by those of steenwi[ck]
in certaine shippes of Enchusen,
at by
e prac[.]
meanes are gone thither w
t
marchandise.
The mater hath bin handled w
t
so much dexter[itie]
at
e Captaines of Enchusen are made acqua[in-]
ted w
t
e plotte, and doe beare
e Enemie in [.]
that they will be ready at all houres, to a[.]
him and his shippes. But there are a cou[ple]
of
e chiefest of
e Bourgmasters there,
at b[.]
corrupted in good earnest, by
e cunning[est]
partie,
at is
e inventor of
e pollicie, and [.]
[wing] no other but
at he and
e Captaines d[o]
in good faith, to betray
e towne unto
e E[nemie]
are wholy ignorant
eat this practise is dis[.]
to
e state. And besides
e forsaid po[.]
to blinde
e Enemie
e more, w
t
a shewe of [.]
assurance,
at his dealing is sincere, is gone [.]
steenwicke in person, and submittes himse[lf to]
punishment, if they speede not of their p[.]
so they rule their proceeding by his direc[tion].
